title: Windows: should we "restrict" usage to "only within git bash"?
body:
May be it is a non-issue, then we would just close.
But IMHO on windows we keep battling issues (e.g. `sh -c` in #5002) which largely arise from heterogeneity of possible windows setups/invocations (from "git bash" or from native windows terminal, e.g. anaconda terminal; may be installed via pip or via conda) and their differential effects on run time. My utopian idea was to just make everything self-contained within conda distribution but I think it would not provide full solution anyways due to intricacy which entering MSYS2 bash entails (filters PATH, changes HOME, etc).  So I think it might benefit if we establish (and ensure by crashing if not so) for now the one and only way `datalad` runtime is used on windows -- in "git bash", so no Windows `$HOME` is expected to be consulted etc, git bundled tools come from git distribution (not e.g. from `m2-bash` under conda).

We can identify that we are running within "git bash" by inspecting `MSYSTEM` env var to be "MINGW64", and `SSH_ASKPASS` be `/mingw64/libexec/git-core/git-gui--askpass`.  `which git` should resolve to `/mingw64/bin/git`.  If not -- kaboom and tell people to run within "git bash" terminal.

edit 1: if we see that `bash` is coming from WSL (and somehow not `/usr/bin/bash`), the battle @adswa was fighting?, we also just fail for starters.

We would need to check what is that `bash` environment used in [github actions](https://github.com/datalad/git-annex/blob/master/.github/workflows/build-windows.yaml) on windows, and if "suitable", retire appveyor setup which I believe runs "windows natively"

later we could explore crazy idea to support "native" windows execution: If `datalad` is executed within a regular Windows command line, (no `MSYSTEM`) -- we can locate `git`, and see if it has `bash` and re-spawn the process as `C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash -c datalad "$@"` of a kind (with any necessary MSYS2 env var flags and possibly as login shell) thus ensuring that whatever `sh` or any command would be ran in a consistent "git bash" environment.
